I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  the  International 
Public Sector Accounting Standards Board (IPSASB) work program for 2019–2021 to improve 
public financial reporting and management capacities in developing member countries of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), with a positive impact on governance, accountability, and 
transparency.1 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and its developmental agenda on good 
governance, anticorruption, and enhanced public financial management (PFM).2 This TA has 
been included in the ADB Management-approved annual work program of the Controller’s 
Department. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The  IPSASB  is  a  standards-setting  body  that  operates  under  the  International 
Federation of Accountants (IFAC).3 The principal activity of the IPSASB is to develop financial 
reporting standards for public sector entities, with the aim of moving toward accrual-based 
International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS) for both developed and developing 
countries. The IPSASB plays a critical role in enhancing the quality and transparency of public 
sector financial reporting and promoting the adoption of the IPSAS. 
 
4.  A key challenge for public sector financial reporting is that many governments still use 
cash-based  accounting  and,  therefore,  provide  minimal  disclosures  compared  with  what 
stakeholders  generally  expect  from  the  private  sector.4 Cash-based  financial  reporting  has 
limitations as it does not provide accurate and complete information on all financial transactions, 
assets and liabilities, and revenues and expenses. The IPSASB encourages public sector 
entities  to  adopt  accrual-based  accounting,  which  reflects  the  full  economic  reality  of 
transactions and provides a comprehensive picture of the financial performance and position of 
public entities.5 This addresses a fundamental aspect of strengthening PFM and enhancing 
accountability and decision-making in the public sector. The IPSASB also believes that a strong 
outreach  program  is  important  to  raise  awareness  of the  IPSAS  and  the  benefits  of their 
adoption. It highlights the importance of capacity building in the public sector as a prerequisite 
for the effective implementation of accrual-based IPSAS. 
 
5.  The pace and scale of IPSAS adoption and implementation have increased significantly 
in recent years. This is a trend that is likely to continue, with the number of governments around 
the world adopting accrual-based accounting estimated to increase from 25% in 2018 to 65% by

economies. 
4  Cash-based accounting is a method of accounting where transactions are recorded when cash receipts and cash 
payments occur. Thus, revenue is recorded when cash is received from customers, and expenses are recorded 
when cash is paid to suppliers and employees. 
5  Under accrual-based accounting, transactions and economic events are recorded when they occur, regardless of 
when cash receipts and payments happen.

2 
the end of 2023.6 Therefore, standards and guidance increasingly will need to meet the practical 
requirements of a significantly expanding user group. 
 
6.  ADB has been providing TA for the IPSASB’s work program since 1997 (in six phases), 
with extensive activities carried out in all the prior phases.7 As of 31 December 2018, there had 
been 42 accrual IPSAS and three recommended practice guidelines issued for the use of public 
sector  entities.  During  phase  six,  10  IPSAS  or  amendments  to  IPSAS  and  other  major 
publications  were  approved  and  issued.  To  date,  the  IPSASB  has  dedicated  significant 
resources to outreach activities; it intends to continue these efforts. 
 
7.  The IPSASB recently conducted a comprehensive review of its broad strategic direction, 
including a public consultation on its strategy and work program during 2019–2023. Based on 
the feedback obtained through the public consultation and many outreach events, the IPSASB 
has confirmed that it should continue to focus its work on developing and maintaining the IPSAS 
and other high-quality financial reporting guidance for the public sector. In addition, the IPSASB 
will  continue  to  raise  awareness  of  the  IPSAS  and  the  benefits  of  accrual  adoption  in 
strengthening PFM. 
 
8.  Recognizing that the development of a high-quality financial reporting standard is a long-
term process, various development partners continue to support the IPSASB, including IFAC, 
which remains the largest fund provider. With the progress made in the first six phases, the 
IPSASB is now seeking support through further TA for 2019–2021. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  public  sector  financial  reporting  and 
management globally strengthened through increasing adoption of accrual-based IPSAS. The 
TA will have the following outcome: decision-making and accountability of public sector entities 
improved and global fiscal stability and sustainability enhanced.8 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
10.  Output  1:  High-quality  financial  reporting  guidance  for  the  public  sector 
developed and maintained. Application of the IPSAS enhances the quality and transparency 
of public sector financial reporting by providing better information for PFM. It has the potential to 
improve decision-making in the public sector, to help governments to be more accountable to 
their  citizens,  and  to  enhance  global  fiscal  stability  and  sustainability.  As  the  international 
standards-setter for the public sector, the IPSASB’s role is to provide governments and other

3 
public sector organizations with high-quality financial reporting standards and other publications 
that will enhance PFM. By developing accrual-based IPSAS, the IPSASB will be assisting 
governments in providing a more comprehensive view of financial position, thereby enhancing 
the credibility and transparency of their financial reporting, which plays an important role in 
improving decision-making in the public sector. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Programs  to  raise  awareness  of  the  International  Public  Sector 
Accounting  Standards  and  the  benefits  of  accrual  adoption  in  strengthening  public 
financial management designed. The IPSASB plans to achieve this output in various ways, 
such  as  working  with  global  and  regional  bodies  to  raise  the  profile  of  the  IPSAS  with 
government officials, financial regulators, and ratings agencies and markets—all of which are 
key advocates needed as consistent supporters of adopting, implementing, and monitoring 
compliance with the IPSAS. The programs will focus on persuading governments to prepare 
accrual-based financial reports using the IPSAS and encouraging users of government financial 
reports to demand better information from governments—information that would be available by 
reporting in accordance with the IPSAS. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the IPSASB work program for 2019–2021 is estimated at $7,698,000, of 
which $330,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. Other donors providing parallel 
cofinancing to IFAC on a grant basis totaling $1,125,000 are (i) the Government of Canada 
($460,000), (ii) the Chartered Professional Accountants of Canada ($460,000), and (iii) the 
Government of New Zealand ($205,000). IFAC will provide the remaining funding requirement 
of $6,243,000. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will not engage consultants for this TA. For the previous six phases of the TA, the 
procurement arrangements were such that all goods and services to be financed out of ADB 
funds should be procured in accordance with the standard procedures of IFAC and acceptable 
to ADB (i.e., produced and supplied from ADB member countries). These arrangements have 
worked well in the last six phases of the TA, and the same arrangements will be implemented in 
this seventh phase. IFAC will implement this TA through the IPSASB, which will ensure that the 
expected outputs are disseminated to the public sector through the publication of new and 
revised IPSAS and outreach activities to engage with stakeholders. 
 
14.  TA implementation will begin in December 2019 and is expected to be completed in 
December 2021. ADB funds will be released in three installments, each totaling $110,000. The 
first installment will be released upon receipt by ADB of the TA letter agreement countersigned 
by IFAC. The two subsequent installments will be released based on the submission of (i) a 
financial statement of accounts, showing the use of grant funds from various funding agencies; 
(ii) audited financial statements of IFAC, with supplementary information on IPSASB projects; 
and (iii) an annual progress report on the project activities supported by the TA. IFAC will 
maintain separate records of ADB financing and provide the following to ADB within 6 months of 
the fiscal year in which the funds are utilized: an annual progress report and audited financial 
statements.

E.  Governance 
16.  A  financial  management  assessment  was  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  staff 
instructions on business processes for TA, as the TA involves the transfer of funds from ADB to 
IFAC, a not-for-profit association. The transfer of funds involves delegated use of a lump sum of 
the TA resources by IFAC, which will administer, procure, and disburse funds for the TA 
activities. The instrument used for the assessment of the TA project’s executing agency was 
ADB’s Financial Management Assessment Questionnaire for Knowledge Partnerships, which 
helps  assess  the  financial  management  capacity  of  the  executing  agency,  funds  flow 
arrangements, accounting policies and procedures, internal and/or external audits, reporting 
and  monitoring,  information  systems,  and  budgeting.  Para.  17  summarizes  the  financial 
management  assessment  of  IFAC.  In  addition,  integrity  due  diligence  was  conducted.  No 
significant integrity risks were identified. 
 
17.  IFAC has no contribution in shares of stocks and has no private sector components in its 
ownership structure. IFAC’s legal status, annual audited reports, organizational structure, and 
governance are available on the IFAC website. IFAC has an accounting system that allows for 
the proper recording of project financial transactions, and controls are in place concerning the 
preparation and approval of transactions, ensuring that all transactions are correctly made and 
adequately explained. Financial statements are prepared in accordance with the IPSAS and are 
audited by an independent external auditor, which is overseen by the audit committee of IFAC. 
IFAC uses Sage Intacct, a cloud-based software, for its accounting and reporting. IFAC has an 
annual budgeting and rolling forecast process that starts in April every year. The budget is 
approved by the IFAC board annually, and forecasts are presented to the board quarterly. There 
were no significant issues noted from the financial management assessment. 
 
18.  The TA categorization is complex because of the information presented in para. 16. 
However, no major technical project risks have been identified, as the IPSASB is competent in 
the subject area. ADB is one of the five donors that will finance the IPSASB budget to carry out 
the work program of the seventh phase. IFAC remains the largest financier of the IPSASB, 
funding about 80% of the total estimated costs. A cofinancing risk of donors failing to commit 
their funding is mitigated as the IPSASB, the largest contributor funding about 80% of the total 
estimated costs, has sound governance and internal controls in place as mentioned in para 17. 
The  remaining  funding  of  20%  will  be  provided  by  four  other  donors  including  ADB,  and 
cofinancing risk for each donor is considered minimal.

5 
19.  ADB will maintain observer status in IPSASB meetings and membership in the IPSASB 
Consultative Advisory Group. ADB’s Controller’s Department will monitor and oversee the TA 
activities, and provide, as needed, direct input to the work of the IPSASB by reviewing the 
consultation papers and exposure drafts and ensuring that ADB member countries’ comments 
are addressed before the final standards and guidelines are issued. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $330,000 on a grant basis for 
Public Sector Accounting Standards (Seventh Phase), and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.
